bill.constitutionalAuthorityStatementText: [Congressional Record Volume 161, Number 132 (Tuesday, September 15, 2015)]From the Congressional Record Online through the Government Publishing Office [www.gpo.gov]By Ms. LOFGREN:H.R. 3509.Congress has the power to enact this legislation pursuantto the following:Article I, section 8 of the Consitution of the UnitedStates.[Page H5980]

item.text: Referred to the House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform.

item.name: Government employee pay, benefits, personnel management
Hybrid, electric, and advanced technology vehicles

summary.text:
Electric Vehicle Charging Offers Modern Utility Terminals for Employees Act or the EV-COMUTE Act

This bill authorizes the head of any federal agency that owns or operates a parking area for use by agency employees to: (1) install, construct, operate, and maintain on a reimbursable basis a battery recharging station in such parking area for the use of privately-owned employee vehicles; and (2) charge a user fee to cover the costs of such station.

bill.title: Electric Vehicle Charging Offers Modern Utility Terminals for Employees Act

item.title: Electric Vehicle Charging Offers Modern Utility Terminals for Employees Act

To authorize any office of the Federal Government which owns or operates a parking area for the use of its employees to install, construct, operate, and maintain a battery recharging station in the area, and for other purposes.
Electric Vehicle Charging Offers Modern Utility Terminals for Employees Act

latestAction.text: Referred to the House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform.

dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.
dublinCore.dc:contributor: Congressional Research Service, Library of Congress
dublinCore.dc:description: This file contains bill summaries and statuses for federal legislation. A bill summary describes the most significant provisions of a piece of legislation and details the effects the legislative text may have on current law and federal programs. Bill summaries are authored by the Congressional Research Service (CRS) of the Library of Congress. As stated in Public Law 91-510 (2 USC 166 (d)(6)), one of the duties of CRS is "to prepare summaries and digests of bills and resolutions of a public general nature introduced in the Senate or House of Representatives". For more information, refer to the User Guide that accompanies this file.
